NRPLUS MEMBER ARTICLE R ecently on Twitter I saw someone make a thread of their favorite meals — the best meals they'd ever eaten. It was all Italian countryside this, New York hole-in-the-wall that, Asian metropolis, Michelin star, and so on, complete with gorgeous pictures. I could remember a few meals I'd had like that. But I found it easier to remember the first times I'd eaten certain things: sushi from a grocery store; roasted peppers on soggy bread with a "tapenade" — whatever that is — in a college dining hall; and, most of all, grilled chicken and rice ...

Being isolated and quarantined makes cooking a social affair ...  culinary bandwagon to create mouth-watering works of art that are being shared on all levels of social media platforms including Youtube, Instagram, Twitter and Facebook. Instructions to make award-winning Chef Christine Cushings famous Quarantine Galaktoboureko Greek custard dessert are available on her YouTube channel. facebook / ChristineCushing.com We're not the only ones on this latest trend. Michelin-star chef Massimo Bottura has been happily cooking up a storm while quarantined with his family in his home in Modena, sharing all these delightful dishes with all of us. So has celebrity chef Jamie Oliver, who has been creating fabulous fare with his adorable children helping out, his lovely wife filming the adventures on her phone. Here in Toronto ...

'Centre of evil' Gasperini said that four days after the Valencia game he felt the worst was over, after a workout like he hadn't had in years and running 10km on the treadmill, but he then lost his sense of taste. A celebratory meal and vintage 2008 Dom Perignon sent by a Michelin-starred chef and Atalanta fan, tasted like "water and bread", Gasperini said. Bergamo, in the northern Lombardy region, was one of the epicentres of the coronavirus pandemic, with many experts believing Atalanta's Champions League game at the San Siro on February 19 to be one of the key causes. Atalanta coach Gasperini reveals he had coronavirus at Valencia game ... -19. "I have antibodies, which does not mean that I am now immune," he added. Gasperini said that four days after the Valencia game he felt the worst was over, after a workout like he hadn't had in years and running 10km on the threadmill, but he then lost his sense of taste. A celebratory meal and vintage 2008 Dom Perignon sent by a Michelin-starred chef and Atalanta fan, tasted like "water and bread", Gasperini said. "I stayed at the Zingonia training ground for three weeks," he continued. "When I did get back to my home in Turin, I always respected social distancing with my wife and children."
